fields.title: Mortgages from Credit Unions
fields.content:
During 2023, credit unions have started to extend ther reach into provision of mortgages.  This is good news for customers, as it means a cohort of people who would not have readily been able to access mortgage and lending services, now have this access in a way that could be considered more accessible than the high-street banks.

Not all credit unions offer mortgages, follow this link to open a new window with a list of credit unions which offer mortgages, by county .

To find your closest credit union follow this link.

Note that many credit unions are currently restricted to customers within a geographic catchment area  determined basd on where the customer lives, or where the customer works.  Find out more about becoming a member here.


  #Purchase a Property
fields.excerpt: -- News :  MORTGAGES now availlable from certain credit unions!! --

fields.title: Education-Dependents
fields.content:
The early years are so expensive as you try to juggle home, work, creche, childminders.  Then maybe a little lull as they progress from primary school to secondary, and the costs of child minding decrease.  Boy oh boy does it come back to bite when they approach college age....!  If your child wants to attend 3rd level this will often involve supporting them to live away from home, meeting college costs, .....


Things to consider like student grant

If Jimmy Joe is moving out of home to live elsewhere would you consider renting out his/her room under the rent-a-room scheme?

Are there any family or friends that he could stay with under a more flexible arrangement when living away from home


If you are fortunate enough to live close to a thrid level institution of choice, what next???


What does the student grant cover?


How can you plan for the student grant??? (ie by reucing your assessable earnings in the tax year prior to offspring attending college)

fields.title: Combining UK and ROI State Pensions
fields.content:
Yes, really!

Its possible to claim a pension if you worked in the UK as well as Ireland. This pension is paid in addition to any Republic of Ireland state pension.

It may be posssible to backdate National Insurance (UK) or PRSI (ROI) contributions to make up for missed contribution (tax-paying) years in each country.

If you worked in the UK for a number of years, then it's worth checking to see if you might be eligible.

For more information see the following links:  Irish Times Money article, 4 June 2023 

Also this article from Davy Financial Planning, 30th May 2023
fields.excerpt: If you worked in the UK for at least 3 years, and also worked in Ireland, it is possible to claim some state pension from both countries....

fields.title: I want to return to Ireland
fields.content:
Things to think about if/when planning a change of residency to Ireland:

Timing: For pay-as-you-earn (most) workers, the tax years runs from 1st Jan to 31st December.  In other countries the tax year mght be different (e.g. UK runs April - April).  Therefore your timing of exit from one country to another may give you the advantage of full-year tax allowances in each contry, e.g.

Tom leaves his fulltime job in the UK and emigrates to Ireland in September.  So from a UK tax perspective, his earnings for the current year are April-September, however he has the benefit of tax credits in the UK for a full year to the following 30th March.

Similarly, on arrival in Ireland, his earning for 4 months Sept-Dec are offset against a full year's tax credits.

Beware: the dreaded EMERGENCY TAX which is applied to your income on first registering with the Irish Revenue.  This is a high rate of tax which is initially applied while your taxation affairs are being first established.  It is likely to be applied for several months and to greatly reduce your take-home pay during this time!   It is important to anticipate this immediate loss of income and to allow for it.  On the plus side, as soon as your Irish taxation is established, any overpaid tax is immediatly refunded.  So in the example of Tom above, he is likely to receive a nice bonus in time for Christmas!  


VISA REQUIREMENTS:  You need to establish whether you (or your dependents who will travel with you) are required to obtain visas before travelling to Ireland.  More information from citizens advice can be found here.   

#Move to Ireland
fields.excerpt: Some of the things you may wish to think about if moving to Ireland from another country

fields.title: Saving and Long Term Investment
fields.content:
What are your savings goals?

What are your savings goals? Here is some feedback from viewers of the RTE programme 'How to be Good with Money' (1min33sec plus ads, opens in new window)   Play video in separate window

Compound Interest can work for, or against you.   

When you are saving, compound interest means that, once the first savings period has passed, you are paid interest on your original savings PLUS the interest already paid.

So your savings grow more quickly

e.g. savings of €100, 5 year term, interest rate 10% p.a.(we wish!)

End of YearSimple InterestCompound Interest
1100 + 100*10% = 110100 + 10 = 110
2110 + 100*10% = 120110 + 110*10% = 121
3120 + 100*10% = 130121 + 121*10% = 133
4130 + 100*10% = 140133 + 133*10% = 146
5140 + 100*10% = 150146 + 146*10% = 160


#Plan my Retirement

#Invest Money

fields.title: FinancialPlanner - Founder Story
fields.content:
First of all, hi there and thank you for reading this!


My name is Deirdre, I'm a mid-50's person who has worked in IT for the last 30 years.  I've always had a love of tech and, after drifting through college in my late teens, found my niche in assembling systems to closely match real-world problems.  I discovered a love of learning and hold numerous academic and vocational qualifications.  My work took me around the world (in the early years); for the last 20 years I've been lucky enough to work close to where I live in the beautiful counties of Wicklow and Carlow in the south-east of Ireland.

Aligned with my professional life is my personal story.  I've been a single parent for many years, and I'm a cancer survivor.  I maintained a middle-income career alongside raising my two sons; this gave me some workplace flexibility but constrained our income. 

My experience of the 'squeezed middle', was earning above social security assistance thresholds, but needing to budget tightly to keep our family stable.  My forensic-level focus on finances are a bit of a family joke.  But, it meant that, even with scarce resources, as a family, we were able to survive and thrive.  And take family holidays and make experiences together (thankfully, I quite enjoy camping!!)

My wish is to create a portal which will empower people....

by highlighting resources to help with financial planning.... 

ENJOY!!                 

#FinancialPlanner - About
fields.excerpt: What motivated me to create this site....

fields.title: FinancialPlanner - How
fields.content:
How?

Financial Planner is a Irish not-for-profit site which aims to help by providing regular, ad-free, impartial financial management guides (articles).   Many articles suggest follow-on tasks (with URL link).  You can copy any of these suggested tasks to your own profile, and can track progress on your own task list. (create, read, update and delete actions from your Task List) 

The site was created in response to a knoweldge gap in financial literacy in Republic of Ireland.  Useful online resources, specific to Ireland, already exist (see our Resources article).  But these can be hard to find, and it's challenging to know which sites are fact-based and relevant.   Information is presented in silos, and its not easy to link information to action.  An integrated view is needed.

Financial Planner's USP is the ability to link authoritative research to the practical steps (tasks) an individual needs to follow to achieve a financial goal.  FP aims to supplement, rather than replace, authoritiative sites; to explain steps needed, and, where possible, to direct the user to the relevant access point (URL) to complete each step. 

By creating a reading list, a user can bookmark Articles for re-reading. By creating a Task list, a user can create and track an action diary. These are visible on the 'MyPlanner' site area once you register an account with us.

How to use the FinancialPlanner site?

Here is a document explaining some of of the site features.  The document is aimed at a technical audience, but may be of some use.  The FP site was developed in Q4 2023 as an academic proof-of-concept, is ad-free and not currently sponsored by any person or organisation. 

As site founder, Deirdre greatly welcomes your suggestions to improve the site's content, features or usability.  Please leave feedback using the  button above.

Thank you for using the FinancialPlanner site, and good luck with your financial journey.

 #FinancialPlanner - About

fields.title: FinancialPlanner - Why?
fields.content:
Why?

Many adults in the Republic of Ireland struggle with financial decision-making*


While there is a lot of good information available online, it can be hard to find and understand. It's hard to know which information to believe, and who to trust.

Navigating complex websites and processes is not easy. Keeping track of which steps you've taken, what's to be done next, and how to find the correct advice for each step. Irish banks have largely withdrawn from offering customer-facing support or guidance. Financial Planner aims to fill that gap!

(*Dept of Finance survey and publications, August 2023)


Following on from awareness of the Department of Finance Initiative, strategic resarch wwas done to establish exactly what is currently available in terms of financial literacy education for Ireland.  Details of this research are here  (a read-only google sheets document)

Based on this research, I wanted to create a site which makes complex information accessible for people.  The principles in creating this site were:

1. Site Purpose:
1.1 To provide access to authoritative financial information and guidance
1.2 To offer persona/role-based navigation to topics of interest ('I want to: buy a house / start a pension....')
1.3 To offer the user an opportunity to interact with topics of interest through bookmarking, liking, copying to a personal folder, making personal notes about a topic
1.4 To offer an alternative to purely text-based navigation of financial guidance/information

2. What type of content will be included:

2.1 links to authoritative articles from trustworthy sites
2.2 Persona-based navigation
2.3 Information presented in varying modes including text, infographics, pictorial, video.
2.4 Interactive capabilities through creation of personal action items, bookmarking, liking
2.5 (Ideally some calculators and games)

3. Features to be included for MVP:
3.1 Django-based articles database allowing admin CRUD facilities for articles
3.2 Django-based themes/categories functionality, manageable by admin with the ability to link articles to a particular theme
3.3 Ability to like and bookmark articles
3.4 User registrations/ signon capabilities

4. Desirable Features
4.1 Ability to associate suggested action items with articles
4.2 Ability to 'copy' suggested actions to a user's personal action list
4.3 Ability for user to maintain (CRUD) their personal action list
4.4 Multimedia presentation of information e.g. infographics
fields.excerpt: Why was the FinancialPlanner site created?  What problem does it aim to address?

fields.title: FinancialPlanner - What?
fields.content:
What?
  • Not-for-profit and ad-free
  • Will not re-use or pass on your information
  • Presents articles based on trusted sources
  • Helps navigate government websites
  • Breaks complex tasks into manageable steps
  • Track the actions you want to take
  • To achieve the best financial outcomes

fields.title: FinancialPlanner - Site Notes
fields.content:
Just keeping these in one place for now... might find their way into one of the other articles:  

styling:  use <div class="FP-content" style="background-color: rgb(209, 231, 221);"> </div> to surround article content

Financial literarcy Content is, in many cases, rich, detailed and valualable.

Government-funded websites such as CCPC, Citizens advice, Revenue offer clear and authoritive advice, and it is possible to determine when the advice was last updated.

Consumer-led sites such as switcher.ie, bonkers.ie, cheapestoil.ie offer comparisons of specific services or products (electricity supplier, telecomms providers, fuel prices) . 

However it is also quite dispersed, and topic searches can require considerable persistence to obtain a full picture.

Truth verification can be difficult, opinion-based sources can appear to hold equal weight with authoritiative sources.  

Vulnerable users researching can fall prey to information-gathering websites which then seek to market or target the customers for revenue-earning purposes, often recycling the customers own information as part of this exercise.

Financial literacy programmes are taking shape in schools, however there does not seem to be entire-life financial educational focus

Bank of Ireland in ther consumer study of XXXXXX, observed that many middle-class parents will gift their children, not only with financial resources, but with the knowledge and learning of how to manage and maintain these resources.

People raised in humble circumstances neither benefit from inherited wealth, nor typically do they absorb this detailed knowledge within their home environment. 

Retail banks, who traditionally prospered through relationship marketing, have since c. 2012 retreated into transactional processing, which reduces the opportunity for customers to learn from conversations with bank staff.  

Post offices, offered as an alternative, are primarily transaction focussed, and reply on unqualified staff who can provide limited financial guidance to customers.

People are being increasingly directed towards self-learning.


But this is challenging because of the huge diversity of information sources and resources.


Therefore, the gap to be adressed is navigational.... how does a user find information relevant to their needs?

fields.title: Mortgage - Early Repayment
fields.content:
PAYING EXTRA AGAINST YOUR MORTGAGE:

Depending on your mortgage terms and conditions, you may be permitted to make additional payments against your mortgage account.  This could be in the form of an extra amount each month, it could be occasional lump sum payments (for example if you receive a bonus at work).   It's important to check how your lender treats additional payments. 

What you are seeking is to offset any additional payments against your mortgage term (ie reduce the duration of your mortgage).  This way, you can greatly reduce the amount you pay in interest against the loan, and can repay it earlier. 

Try the Google Sheets mortgage calculator (see   button above this Article)

It is a real surprise to see the effect that an additional payment, particularly in the early years, can have on the total paid.  It means each subsequent monthly payment is allocated less to interest repayment and more to capital (loan balance) repayment.

If you are in a position to make (either one off or regular) additional mortgage payments, check how these are dealt with for YOUR mortgage policy.   Start a discussion with your lender, and make the additional payments when suits you... 


#Purchase a Property, #Plan My Retirement #Plan my Retirement
fields.excerpt: The benefits of making extra payments against your mortgage... plus a handy Google Sheets calculator so you can try out the figures....

fields.title: Show Her The Money
fields.content:
Show her The Money is both a movie and a movement

Its a movie which profiles 4 female founders, who are trading successfully and who require investment to expand. The movie highlights the difficulties that women experience navigating this part of the financial world, which is male-dominated and not particularly welcoming towards female entrepreneurs.   Women are required to engage with non-vaue-add 'prove-yourself' processes.  'We don't want charity, we want parity!' runs the theme tune.   

Dapper Boi is a gender-neutral clothing range which includes jeans with practical deep pockets, shirts with additional between-button fasteners to avoid the 'chest gap' often experienced by women with button-front garments.  As its founder, xxxx, says - we designed these garments with women in mind, but then guys approached us and said 'hey I too have butt cheeks, I want to wear your jeans'.     

Pocket Sun started an investement company in her mid-20s.  Initially the financial institutions she dealt with were sceptical of her youth and inexperience, but she now handles XXXXX funds and points out that the investment metric returns most when a company is pre-public, that women are a strong investment as they tend to employ capital wisely and XXXXXly (using the money in imaginative ways to overcome obstacles).

XXXX is a post-mastectomy lingerie company, the founder, XXXXX talked about her grandmothers life after breast cancer, watching her shopping for mastectomy-friendly underclothes, relegated to sterile aisles of chemist and pharmacies, 'next to the adult diapers'.  XXXX shows the beautiful clothing, and demonstrates skintone-matching mastectomy forms.

Dennys is a large restaurant chain across the USA,  it operates as a franchise model.   The largest female franchisee is XXXXX, a glamorous entrepreneur who tells her heartwrenching journey 'I came from nothing.  At 17 years old, I started front-of-house but then realised the waitresses were the ones making all the money.  I begged my manager to let me work as a waitress'.  At the time of making the movie (c. 2022) she owned XX franchises.

XXXX has now become an investor.  We heard her views from the investment perspective, as well as 4 other investors.  What they had in common was a clear sense of their own purpose, what they were willing to invest in, and the sought clarity of purpose from their clients.  'Nothing bad comes when women have more money'.

An important part of the 'Show Her the Money' movie roadshow is the panel discussion which follows.  The film-maker and investor, Catherine Gray explains her motivation in touring to 50 locations with the movie..... The panel in Dublin consisted of an additional 5 international female entrepreneurs.  They talked of their successes, the obstacles they'd to overcome in personal and professional life, and how they had built their empires, sorry businesses.... 

XXXX launched her auyverdic skincare range in the Indian market.  Again there was a nod to her female lineage, with her mother making skincare products at home as she grew up.

The funny thing about this movie was that we saw the personal and family situation of each of the founders.  Each had a family, children, and a network they were socially responsible for.  The warmth of those relationships and the emotional journeys juxtapositioned with business activity was unusual to see.  Corporate success is often portrayed for women as dual (didactic or whatever the word is) where family life is one slio and business life in another.  Here we saw the intermingling of both which looked like a much more ecological natural flow.

An unspoken message was that entrepreneurial journeys, particularly when undertaken with a supportive partner, can combine family and professional lives, perhaps in a way that the corporate journey struggles with.  Women in corporate roles are often required to 'mask' their family lives, to pretend not to have responsibilities and committments outside work.  

Coming full circle, I was delighted to see one attendee in Dublin with her daughter, and another with a younger child.

fields.title: Economic Abuse
fields.content:
ECONOMIC ABUSE

In the wanderings of my recent stakeholder-and-funding research I came across a charity (which is elegible for funding under the AIB Community award scheme.  Registered charity #1173256 in the UK).

'Surviving Economic Abuse' https://survivingeconomicabuse.org/

A charity which makes the clear link between coercive control and economic abuse in a relationship.

And identifies how economic abuse can continue long after a relationship has ended.

And which has campaigned for parlimentary law to recognise and deal with economic abuse.

Founded in 2016, this charity makes a difference every day to women and their lived experience. 

----------------------

I since became aware of one of the irish banks training keyworkers in women's refuge on financial literacy topics.  This is a significant initiatve in Ireland

fields.excerpt: Its a good idea to check in with your finances at least one a year.  This helps you step back from the day-to-day and see the big picture of how you are progressing against your own long term goals.
